field_edited_text.value:
Trains still travel the streets through Fells Pt.







ssues and Problems

The prospect of a significant growth in
residential development poses several
important issues for Fells Point and the
Canton waterfront.

First, there are the potential difficulties
that could develop between the newer resi-
dents and long-term residents. The influx
of new residents could dilute the influence
over community activities exercised by resi-
dents who have lived in Fells Point and
Canton for many years. This in turn could
undermine the uniquely European quality
and stable home ownership which has
been one of the area’s appealing character-
istics. The influx of new residents also pre-
sents a potential economic threat to Fells
Point and Canton’s long-standing residents.
It is feared that the influx of new residents,
who are able to pay much higher prices for
their homes, will drive up property values
so high that moderate-income residents
will no longer be able to afford to pay pro-
perty taxes and will have to leave the com-
munity. Both the social and economic
issues posed by the rapid development of
more expensive housing in Fells Point and
by adjacent construction in Canton will
have to be addressed if the communities
are to retain the diversity that are their
hallmark.

A second issue raised by the changing
character of the area is the provision of an
adequate number of parking spaces for the
new uses, including residential and com-
mercial development and the proposed
marinas. If all the proposed marina slips in
the Fells Point/Canton waterfront were
developed as commercial facilities between
600 and 750 parking spaces would have to
be provided. This in addition to spaces
required for new apartments and condo-
miniums, offices, shops and restaurants.
There are clearly not enough spaces cur-
rently available. Larger projects will have to
consider new parking structures or convert-
ing portions of older buildings into parking
facilities.

Another issue is the potential conflict
between the new housing development and
industrial activity in the area. New middle-
and-upper-ihcome residents are not likely
to enjoy the truck traffic, trains, noise, and
dust associated with heavy industry. At the
same time the City will not want to dis-
courage job-creating industries by severely
restricting the scope of their activity. The
difficult challenge facing the City in the
years ahead will be to situate and phase
new residential development to minimize
direct conflicts with existing industry.

Another arena of potential conflict is
the harbor itself. Many of the proposals for
waterfront housing in both Fells Point and
Canton include marinas in their plans. As
the number of pleasure craft docked on the
shoreline grows there is increasing likeli-
hood of conflicts with the work boats sta-
tioned at Fells Point and other areas of the
harbor. To avoid potential conflicts, marina
proposals will be reviewed with commer-
cial shippers and towing companies so that
revisions can.be made to the plans to insure
the safety of the waterways for all vessels.
The City is also preparing guidelines for
marina development to assist in the loca-
tion, configuration, and size of future
marinas.

A final issue is insuring that private
developers of waterfront land continue to
provide public access to the shoreline.
While most of the shoreline in Fells Point
and Canton is privately owned, it is City
policy that the public at large be guaran-
teed access t8 the harbor, which is consi-
dered a public resource. As development in
Fells Point and Canton increases, the City
will continue to work with developers to
design public walkways, parks, and prome-
nades compatible with the privately spon-
sored projects.



95
